hero.title: Research & Experiments
hero.subtitle: Advancing plant resilience through cutting-edge phenotyping and stress analysis

overview.title: Research Overview
overview.description: Our research focuses on understanding plant responses to environmental stresses through advanced phenotyping technologies. We conduct comprehensive studies examining heat stress, drought stress, and combined stress conditions across controlled greenhouse environments and field settings.

experiments.name: Heat Stress Studies
experiments.description: Investigating plant physiological responses to elevated temperature conditions

experiments.name: Drought Stress Analysis
experiments.description: Examining water deficit impacts on plant growth and development

experiments.name: Combined Stress Conditions
experiments.description: Studying interactive effects of multiple environmental stressors

settings.description: Controlled environment studies with precise regulation of temperature, humidity, light, and irrigation to isolate specific stress variables and enable detailed phenotyping.
Real-world agricultural settings providing natural stress conditions and validating greenhouse findings under production environments with complex environmental interactions.

methods.title: Methods & Technologies
methods.description: Our lab employs state-of-the-art phenotyping technologies and analytical methods to capture comprehensive plant trait data across multiple scales and modalities.

technologies.name: PlantEye 3D Scanner
technologies.purpose: High-resolution 3D laser scanning system for structural phenotyping
technologies.applications: Weekly scans throughout growth cycles to track morphological changes

technologies.name: OAK-D Cameras
technologies.purpose: Spatial AI cameras with depth perception for multi-modal imaging
technologies.applications: Daily automated imaging for continuous monitoring

technologies.name: Hyperspectral Imaging
technologies.purpose: Advanced spectroscopy for biochemical and physiological trait assessment
technologies.applications: Weekly spectral measurements to detect physiological stress before visual symptoms

technologies.name: Chlorophyll Fluorescence
technologies.applications: Bi-weekly measurements during critical growth stages

technologies.name: Machine Learning Pipeline
technologies.purpose: Advanced data processing and predictive modeling
technologies.applications: Integration of multi-modal data for comprehensive analysis

workflow.description: Systematic acquisition of multi-modal phenotyping data using automated imaging systems and manual measurements
Rigorous validation and preprocessing to ensure data integrity and remove artifacts or outliers
Automated extraction of quantitative traits from raw sensor data using computer vision and signal processing
Application of mixed models, ANOVA, and multivariate techniques to identify significant treatment effects
Development and validation of predictive models for stress detection and yield forecasting
Cross-validation with independent datasets and dissemination through peer-reviewed publications

experiments.title: Ongoing & Completed Experiments
experiments.description: Our experimental portfolio spans multiple crop species and environmental conditions, generating comprehensive datasets for understanding plant stress responses.

studies.title: Multi-Cultivar Heat Tolerance Screening
studies.objective: Identify heat-tolerant genotypes through comprehensive phenotyping of 50 cultivars under controlled heat stress conditions
findings: Identified 8 high-performing genotypes with <2¬∞C canopy temperature increase
Chlorophyll fluorescence shows early stress detection capability (10 days pre-symptom)
Strong correlation (r=0.82) between early-stage vigor and final yield under stress

studies.title: Drought Recovery Dynamics Study
studies.objective: Characterize recovery trajectories following water deficit across developmental stages
findings: Early vegetative stage drought has minimal long-term impact with adequate recovery
Flowering stage stress reduces yield by 35-45% regardless of recovery period
Rapid root system recovery (48-72h) predicts better overall plant resilience

studies.title: Field-Scale Combined Stress Monitoring
studies.objective: Validate greenhouse findings under natural field conditions with multiple concurrent stresses
findings: Field heterogeneity creates natural stress gradients for model validation
Thermal imaging correlates well with ground-based stress measurements (r=0.76)
ML models predict yield with 85% accuracy 4 weeks pre-harvest

studies.title: High-Throughput Spectral Phenotyping
studies.objective: Develop rapid spectroscopic methods for stress detection in breeding programs
findings: PRI index shows highest sensitivity to water stress (AUC=0.91)
Integration with breeding databases enables rapid trait mapping
